The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: OUR JAPANESE VISITORS
div.p: When the Japanese squadron visits the Egyptian ports--- though the date of this occurrence is not yet settled—we can imagine that the public will show the utmost interest not only in the vessels that went through the stress of the first great naval war fought under modern conditions, but in the men who manned them. The fight of August 10, 1904, had for all the navies an importance that cannot be under-estimated. It showed the importance of straight shooting with the heavy gun, and its fruit was the Dreadnought. The victory of the Sea of Japan proved even more decisive:

its lessons are to-day vigorously discussed by sailors of every nation, and the men whose boyhood was passed under a feudal regime, whose first war-vessels were junks whose first arms arrows and swords, have taught the world fresh lessons in naval warfare.

Yet these achievements, great as they were, were not in our opinion the greatest to the credit of the Japanese navy. On a foggy day in May the Japanese fleet, cruising off Port Arthur, ran into a minefield. The battleships Hatause and Yashima and the swift cruiser Yoahino were lost. In a few minutes,without a shot being fired, the Japanese fleet had lost one- third of its battleship strength and one of the fastest of its scouts. It was faced by an equal force of vessels in Port Arthur and behind all by the menace of the Baltic fleet, and for a moment it seemed that the four modern battleships that remained could not hope to maintain even the semblance of a blockade of Port Arthur. Yet the Japanese faced the impossible and performed it. The crew of the Yashima wrote long letters home describing the sinking of the Hateuse (which the Russians had witnessed) and stating that all was well with their ship. The fleet continued its blockade—a patriotic and silent corps of officers breathed no word of the great misfortune that had befallen them, and so little did even the Russians dream of their own success in sinking one-third of the Japanese battle fleet that many of the combatants in the fight of August 10 declared that they had seen the Yashima in the hostile line, though it is now known that the islanders pitted four battleships against six on that day and four against eight on May 28, 1905.

It is this quality that is, in our opinion, one of the strongest naval and military assets of Japanese power—the quality that has enabled them to face risks undaunted by losses : something higher than mere obstinacy, and more reliable than mere élan. Stubbornness, fortitude, whatever name you will, it is one of the greatest aids to victory. Other islanders have, after arduous wars, retired to their armchairs, composed treatises on "the lessons of the War," and neglected their forces. Japan, while following no aggressive course of expansion, has no desire or intention to dream over her hard-won triumphs. Fresh ships are constructing in her yards and in a few years' time, by 1915 at latest, the Island Empire will be in possession of Dreadnoughts backed by powerful squadrons of older battleships and fast and well-armed cruisers. Her statesmen are pacific ; by it they have realised to the full that, without preparation for war, peaceful intentions cannot lead a nation through the labyrinth of international politics.

div.head:
GERMANY AND PEACE.
ATTITUDE TOWARDS HAGUE CONFERENCE.

div.p: The "Colonge Gazette publisheds a telegram from Berlin announcing the the Chancellor had received Mr. Stead. The former declared to him that German, like other countires, considers it her duty to endeavor, in the second Hague Conference, to forward the peoples rights in the name of humanity. Germany can do this all the better because she has not been engaged in war for more that a generation, and has adopted as her aim the preservation of peace. It is for that reason that the Imperial Government has accpted Russia's invitaition and has studied in a friendly spirit all the items of the programme.

The programme appears to contain questions requiring above all a pacific soultion. As to the wishes of private individuals expressed by Mr. Stead to the Chancellor, the altter proved to him how seriously Germany is taking the Hague Conference, but recalled the proverb: "Who grasp much holds little". The Chancellor added that the extension of the programme, which ahs already become a part of the business of the conference, might raise serious objectsion on many sides which would have in any case to be submitted and examined with attention.

Mr. Stead appears to have gathered from the conversation the impressiont that Germany is in now way, as many people say, opposed to the pacific efforst which find their inception in the Conference, and that she sincerely wishes to participate in this important undertaking, although she objects to the overburdening of the programme, which has already become a mass of useful questions capable of solution.
(Reuter)
Herr Horman, Progressive candidate, has been elected at Bremen, defeating Herr Schmalfeldt. Socialist candidate.
Up to the present the Socialists have lost 22 seats and gained 1.
The majority of the ballots will have taken place by Tuesday next.
(Reuter)

Mr. John Redmond, speaking at Waterford, reiterated that nothing but an Irish Parliament with an executive council responsible to it would satisfy the Nationalists. If the Government Bill is calcualted to retard Home Rule they would reject.
(Reuter)

(Official) Lord Charles Beresford has been appointed to the command of the Channel Fleet, Sir A. G. Curon-Howe to the Atlantic Fleet, Sire E.S. Poe to the Cape Fleet, and Rear-Admiral Bridgeman to the Home Fleet.
(Reuter)

The Port Kingston has arrived at Avonmouth from Jamica with Sir Alfre Joues and Messrs. Hamar Greenwood and Henniker-Heaton on board. They paid a tribute to Sir J. Swettenham, saying that nobody could have behaved better amid the chaos which prevailed in Kingston.
(Reuter)
A great fire has occurred in the business section of Harrisburg (Pennsylvania), which was uncontrollable for several hours. The damage done is estimated at 1,000,000 dollars (R.)
Lady Dorothy Cuthbert was pheasant shooting at Beaufront Castle when her husband's gun went off accidentally and killed her. (R.)

The differenc between M. Clemencean and M. Briand regarding the administration of the Separation Law thretens to bring about a crisis in the Cabinet. The extreme Radicals are dissatisfied with M. Briand's concessions.
(Reuter)
Their Majesties will both stay at the Embassy during their visit to Paris. The visit is quite a surprise: is is supposed to be a pleasure trip, but is naturally regarded as strengthening the Entente.
(Reuter)
There has been a renewal of the blizzard in Yorkshire.
(Reuter)
The city is snowbound: the traffic is suspended. Extraordinary snowballing scenes have led to wholesale arrests by the police. (R.)

The outbreak of cerebral meningitis in Glascow has become an epidemic. There were 103 cases in january, of which 51 have turned fatal. Additional cases are treated daily. Fifty per cent of the illness is among children. Two more deaths among children have occurred at Belfast.
(Reuter)
The steamer Clavering, bound for Japan, has been wreaked at the mouth of the Tees. Three men have been drowned and forty are missing
(Reuter)
The S.S. Clavering has become a total wreak. The lifeboats suceeded in reaching the vessel to-day and rescued 41 surviors. 21 persons have been drowned, of whom 19 are Asiatics.
Dailt arests throughout the lower Yangtse valley of students returned from Japan, compled with the marked successes of the reactionaries in peking, is causing consternation among the reform party.
(Reuter)
M. Gunther succeeds M. Polonyi as Minister of Justice.
(Havas)

div.head: POST OFFICE DEFRAUDED.
div.p: 8,000 OF FORGED MONEY ORDERS.
Naples, January 1.

The police have arrested an employe of the Cairo Post Office, who gives his name as George Bey, and declares having made out before his departures forged money orders on Italian offices for sums amounting to 200,000 francs.
(Havas)

On enquiry at the G.P.O this morning, we were informed that some forged Egyptian money orders, to the amount of 8,000, had been detected in the Italian postal service. After an exchange of telegrams between that service and the G.P.O, Alexandira, all means were taken to stop payment and arrest the forger. According to a telegram received by the postal authorities last night, this had been done, and the man, who gives the name of R. George Bey, is a present under examination.

Such a name as George Bey is unknown amoung the emploes of the Egyptian Postal Administration, and it is therefore considered to have been falsely addumed. The man arrested is probably of local origin, and he may have issued the money orders here and then left the country for Italy in order to cash them.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE
div.p: This year's pilgrimage is a striking testimony to the present prosperity of Egypt, and to the well being of it population, for the number of Egyptian pilgrims has exceeded that of any previous season.

No less than 18,000 Egyptians left Suez for the Holy Land of Islam, and it must be borne in mind that each has to pay in advance for tickets there and back by the Khedivial Mail Line-- the only line authorized by the Government-- at the rate of P.T. 500; pay for his passport; make a deposit to cover the quarentine due, and moreover take with him enough moneu to defray the considerable cost of the land journey and his sojourn in Meccas and Medina.

Turkish, Russian and North African pilgrims who passed through Egypt on the pilgrimage were no less than 14,000. Of these, the Turks and Russians are generally well-provided for, but the pilgrims from Morocco, Algeria, Tunis, and Tripoli arrive often in a lamentable state of destitution which is dangerous to public health and an annoyance to their co-religionists as well as the authorities of the towns through which they pass, as they frequently have not the money to pay either for their nourishment or passage, which have thus to be paid by the public.

div.head: HELOUAN RACES
div.p: Quite a number of people journeyed down to Helouan for the races, many of them arriving in the time for lunch beforehand. Some seventy hungry visitors beyond those staying at the hotel trooped into the dining hall at the Grand; and even more turned up at the Tewfik, having taken advantage of the tickets issued which cover all the expenses of railway, lunch, tea, and entrance to the race course. Mr. and Mrs. Stout, who were accompanied by Mrs. Stone, were early on the scene, and Mr. and Mrs. Shreiber were also there with Miss Hurley. Mrs. and Miss Crofton were with Mrs. and Miss Carey and Miss Fox, and Mrs. and Miss leverich also patronized the meeting. The Countess Caroly had with her her pretty daughter, and Miss Sursock and Miss Loutfahlah were together. Mrs. Wynne and Miss Blythe were taking deep interest in the proceedings of the afternoon, and Mrs. Huteson looked particularly sporting in her trim tailor-made get-up. Miss de Wahl, who has only just returned to Egypt, was accoumpanied by her younger sister, and Capt. and Mrs. Bailer and Capt. and Mrs. Gillson were also noticed. Mrs. Nungovich and Miss Nungovich had various friends with them; and the Marquis de Fioravanti and Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., were also noticed among the spectators. The Comtesse Hollenstein also patronized the meeting, being accompanied by the Comte; and most of the Helouan residents and visitors were present, their names being too numerous to mention.

The sport witnessed was above the average character, both in class and form shown. The fields turned out in good number excepting for the last race, which was for a cup presented by the George Nungovich Hotels Company, and open to all classes of race horses in Egypt. Owing to the prejudice against running horses in sand only two English horses faced the started at this race. The course was excellent on the whole, with the exception of three wet patches. There were no slips or mishaps of any kind. After the big race of the day (the Helouan Derby) was run, Prince Halim, on behalf of himself and the stewards of the Helouan Sporting Club, presented Mr. A.J. Michaelides with a very handsome silver trophy in recognition of his valuable services as honorary secretary of the club from 1903 to 1906 inclusive, during which time he has worked indefatigably, and brought the club up to its present condition of popularity and made it one of the most up-to-date sporting associations in Egypt.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON, M.P.
div.p: FAREWELL BANQUET.
Mr. J. M Robertson, M.P., whose visit to Egypt has aroused so much interest among the native population, was entertained at a farewell dinner at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, last night.
At the conclusion, of an excellent repast, Mr. Hafiz Dawad delivered the following post-prandial oration: --

"It has been my good fortune to have seen and associated much with Mr. Robertson during his stay in our country, and now, I think, it is my duty to convey to him at this moment, when we are expressing our farewell greetings, the pleasure and gratitude felt by all my compatriots who had the privlege of meeting and speaking with him; and appreciating his high qualities and noble aims.

"I take this opportunity to assure Mr. Robertson that these Egyptians will never forget the days, hours or even moments which it was their good fortune to have spent in his company and in conversing with him. I am sure it leaves in them a memory which they will forever cherish and it will be always mingled with their loyalty to and love for their country.

"I expressly desire to refrain on this occasion from indulging in politics, for anything of the sort might be misinterpreted, and therby injure the cause which we desire to serve, namely, to further the advancement of Egypt by establishing harmonious relations between the English and our own nation, and to obtain the right and natural share for our people in the government of their country.

"I also wish to take this opportunity of assuing Mr. Robertson that he has, already during his too short visit to Egypt, rendered his courty a great service by leaving in the hearts of the Egpyitans the best example for the noble character of the English nation. Gentlemen I ask to drink to the health of honoured guest."
Mr. Robertson replied as follows:--

"In thanking you for the extremely kind sentiments expressed by my friend Hafiz Effendi Awad, with which you so amiably associate yourselves, I will first take the opportunity to express my deep sense of obligation to Hafiz Effendi himself for all he has done to make my stay in Egypt both pleasant and instructive. But for his constant help, I could not have seen or learned the greater part of what I have seen and learned from my intercourse with Egyptians of all grades and my perambulations in the country. He has been my guide, philosopher and friend in Egypt. He has enabled me, above all things, to know men with whom I could not otherwise have conversed, and whose friendship I am glad to have gained and he has been himself a constant source of light to me.

"As he has said, we are not here to-night to discuss in detail the problems of politics, but to testify to each other our mutual regard, and our common aspirations. As you are aware, I hold the well-being of my own country to be involved in the well-being of those with which she is connected, and I am in sympathy with you not only on the score of the great moral law of reciprocity, but because of my conviction that whatever England can do to promote your social and political progress will redound to her own advantage.

"And in saying this I am concious of expressing the feeling of those whom I regard as the best among my countrymen. The fact that others of my countrymen may be opposed to me is for me of no special improtance. In every healthy community, men are daily being divided on questions, concerning themselves: if they were to be wholly at one on questions concerning foreigners it would be a couse for suspicion rather than for satifaction as to the justice of their motives.

"What you and I alike stand for tonight is the great principle of good-will between nations-- that principle which is more and more dominating the thoughts of politicians, in all civilised countries. We British Liberals are satified that the better nations known each other the better friends they will be, and if Englishmen feel this with regard to the people of France, Germany and Russia, how could they fail to acknowledge it in regard to the people of Egypt, with whom they have been so long and so intimately connected? I am convinced that they will more and more respond to the needs of the situation as it now exists. We, who are here, seek to rise above misunderstandings and to rectify the errors of the past. I have no title to speak for the authorities, but I have the right as a British citizen to say that I know multitudes of my countrymen have no stronger wish in your regard than to understand your needs and your appeals to deal with you as friends; to remedy your just grievances; and to realise as far as may be and as soon as may be your reasonable asprirations.

" So may it be. You on your part will not refuse to recognise the difficulties of our task. but where there is mutual goodwill, such difficulties are in time surmountable. In the name of that mutual goodwill and that common hope I ask you to drink with me the toast of what I will take leave to call 'The moral health of Egypt.'"
Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., then spoke as follows:--

It is not my intention to say anything to-night about politics. My reason for so abstaining is, first, that I am not sure how far my personal opinions in regard to the Egyptian question are in accord with those of many, if not most, of the guests assembled at this hospitable board; and I should be sorry to disturb in any way the harmony of the meeting.

"I do not pretend to be an authority on the Egyptian question. the longer I have lived in this beautiful land of yours which to me is almost a second home country, the more deeply I have impressed by the conviction that between the East and the West there lies a gulf, which is impassable from one side to the other.

"All I can fairly say for myself is that having been a frequent visitor to Egypt for more years than I like to recall, and having, when absent, followed closely the course of events in Egypt, I am perhaps better able that most people to judge of the progress made between the years 1868 and 1907. I am bound honestly to tell you that during the above period, whatever may be the advance of Egypt from a material point of view, the moral and political situation seems to me have undergone very little change.

"That his should be so is, I believe, bot so much the fault of the indivicduals as of natual circumastances. Judging by my own observation, I should say that change of any kind in Egypt must be very slow, and that any change, to be permanent, must be made step by step, and be based not on abstract ideas but in accordance with the traditions and customs which have prevailed her for countless generations.

"I should like, if you would permit me to offer you a word of advice, to remark that one of the chief benefits England has derived from her peculiar institutions has been that political differences are seldom, or never, allowed to affect personal relations. We areso used to see parties change their policy, and politicians change their party, that we have long learned the turth that our antagonists of to-day may be our supporters to-morrow, and that any real reform must be based on preactical expendiency,– not on logical principles.

"ON this account, I am glad to be present at this meeting, and to bid good-bye to the guests of the evening. It would be difficult probably, to find two men whose political ideas are more at variance with one another with regard to English politcs, that Mr. Malcolm Robertson and the humble individual who now addresses you. What he and his party think right, I and my party think worng. Yet, for all this we meet here-- and I have no dount shall meet at home-- as friends who are both alike interested in the Egyptian question. Not knowing precisely in the Egyptian questions. Not knowing precisely what his views about Egypt may be except from the interesting discourse to which we have just listened, I am prepared to believe that any views he may give utterance to at home are held by him after careful thought and study, and are supported by the information he has been enable to acquire here during his brief visit.

"I feel equal confidence that, if the views he may propound upon Egypt, either in parliament or in the Press, should be such as I may feel bound to criticise in print, Mr. Robertson will give me credit not only for coutresy but for an honest wish to speak what I, rightly or wrongly, believe to be the truth.

"It is not probable that my age and state of health will permit me to visit Egypt for many more years to come. All I can say is that so long as I live, I shall always bear gratefully in mind the invariable kindness and hospitality I have received from well-nigh very resident in Egypt, whatever may have been their nationality or creed, and of which the recpetion you gentlement have given me to-night is the latest, though I trust not the last incident."

Among the guests present were Mr. E. Dicet, C.B., Hassan Rafky Pasha, Hussein Pasha Wassif, Sheikh Aly Youssef, Sayed Hassan Mousa El Akkad, Youssef Bey Saddik, Hassan Vey Bakry, Shafik Bey El Harmil, Ahemd Bey Lutfy, Chams El Din Hamouda Bey, Abdul Hamid Omar Bey, Mr. Bernie Mansfield, Mohamed Eff. Massoud, Daoud Eff. Barakat.

Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., arrived at Alexandira this afternoon at 1 o'clock and went to the Khedivial Hotel, where he was entertained to lanch by Mahmond Effendi El-Bagouri, the representative at Alexandira of "Al Moayad." About tweleve presons were invited to the repast.

Mr. Robertson has a photograph taken of himself in the midst of a group of natives at Denishwai. He is represented surrounded by Hafiz Effendi Awad, Editor of "Al Minbar," Mohamed Bey Ammar, a notable of Alexandria, Shefik Bey el-Hermil, Hussein Effendi Hermil, Mohamed Bey el-Khadem, and Mahmound Effendi el-Bagouri, of "Al Moayad."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer and the Advisers, Sir Horace Pinching, Col. Macauley Bey, and other high officials are leaving this afternoon for Galioub, where they will attend the inaugration of the new hospital erected by Shawarbi Pasha.

Lady Anne Dorothy Cuthbery, whose terrible dealth is reported by Reuter to-day, was the daughter of the 5th Early of Stafford, and wife of Capt. James Harold Cuthbert, D.S.C., late of the Scots Guards, who went through the South African campaign.

Mr. C. E. Vexey, who has been appointed to the position of assistant genreal manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son. (Egypt), Ltd., arrived in Cairo on the 28th ulto. and will take up his new duties at once.

div.head: Ulema Commission.
div.p: The Ulemna Commission meets on Thursday next at the Ministy of Justice under the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Fuad.

div.head: Victoria House and Nurses' Home, Alexandria.
div.p: The annual general meeting will be held at Vitoria House on Wednesday. 6th inst., at 5:30 p.m. All interest are invited to attend.

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: Ahemd Bey Shefik paid a visit yesterday on the behalf of the Khedive to Sheikh Hassouna el Nawawi, to whom he presented his Highness's feliciations.

div.head: Egyptian Directory.
div.p: The "Aunuaire Egyptien" for 1907 has been printed, and the volumes are now in the hands of the bookbinders. They will be distributed and on sale in a few days time.

div.head: Helouan Development Co.
div.p: Mr. Alfred Chamas, director of the Cairo Omnibus Cmmpany, formerly agent of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt in the Moudirieh of Galioub, has resigned his position on the board of directors of the Helouan Development Co.

div.head: The Zionist Movement.
div.p: Our contemporary the "Hashkafa," which is published at Jerusalem, announces that the board of managers of the Anglo-Palestine Bank have decided to make Hebrew the offical language of the Bank for its internal sevice.

div.head: L'Union Fonolere d'Egypte.
div.p: This company has just received an offer for one thousand feddans of its property in the Gharbieh province at L.E. 100 per feddan, for which is paid originally L.E. 55 per feddan. Owning to the great rise in the value of agricultural land the company has though fit to refuse the offer.

div.head: Naval Visit to Alexandria.
div.p: A division of the Austro-Hungarian Navy, under the command of the Rear-Admiral Ziegler, whose flagship is the turret ironclad Archduke Charles, is exprected here in the course of the annual cruise in the Levant, the other ports of call being Patras, the Piraeus, Salonica, Smyrna, and Syria. The new turrent ironclad Archduke Frederick will form part of the division.

div.head: SPECIE WITHDRAWLS.
div.p: Regarding the arrival in London of 500,000 from Egypt this month, which it is understood is to be earmarked for India, there appears to be some doubt in the London market as to whether the Reserve may not be drawn upon in anticipation, which would cause a temporary reduction.

Under the arrangements made for the grant of telegraphic transfers on india against soverigns shipped to England from abroad the Secretary of State for India in Council has purchased 100,000 due from Egypt on or about February 10.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: Since by now we have learny no to be overexacting the question arises as to whether it be preferable to witness a good opera badly given or a poor one well given, and if we plump for the latter we should certainly find little to say in favour of yesterday's divertissement (for this is all "Un Ballo in Maschera" amounts to). On the other hand, we can conscientiously approve its performance. After all, it is far pleasanter and less troublesome to praise than to blame, and there is no reason for incurring the wrath of an enraptured public (who hum and beat time ad nauseam) by attacks upon so weak and decrepit a thinkg as this. let us rather say that Sig. de Marchi was in better voice than we have yet heard him, although his cold is evidently still troubling him, whereby he is ts times apt to be nasal. We sill have an expectation of better achievements later on. Signa de Lerma's Ameila was a very creditable and painstaking affair, and, if some of her high notes show more power than accuracy this was no hinderance to her obtaining a large share in the applause which was lavishly bestowed.

PROSPECTUS

The Egyptian Economical Residences Cy a pour object : la construction, l'exploitation, a location, la datation ou prise a bail, l'achar, la vente au comptant ou par paiements échelonautres, pour son compte personnel ou en participation, la gérance d'habitations a bon marché ou autres; l'achat, la vente de terrains ruraux on urbains ainsi que toutes opérations com-merciales, industrielles ou finsncieres se rattachant de près ou de loin au but social tant en sou nom personnel qu'en participation et cela dans la plus large conception de l'idée sans que l'énoncé précédent puisse être considéré comme restrictif.

La Société vient d'acheter dans des conditions de prix et de paiement très avantageuses environ 9920 mètres carrés de terrain à bâ ir sis entre le Z ber et la Route de l'Abbassieh, au point connu sous le nom d'anoieu abattoir, divisés en plusieurs lots.

Elle a acquis aussi avec grandes facilites de paiement, la propriété connne sons le nom de Pelais Yegben d'une contenance de 20,000 mètres carrés environ sis à Seronghieb, dans un des centres les pins populeux du Caire, anx environs de Khan Khalil, de la Sekka Guédida, du Modski, de la Place Mansour Pacha, du Gouvernorat et des Tribunaux Mixtes, presque en bordure du Boulevard Mohammed Aly.

Les employés des Banques et du Commerce y trou veront aux environs des lieux de leur travail des logements confortables dont la proximité leur évitera des pertes de tomps sans les obliger a des dépenses de transport.
La démolition des énormes bâtisses qui oonstitoent le Palais Yegben et la vente des matériaux en provenant seront mises immédiatement en adjudication.

La Société se propose d'édifier ensuite, des constructions de plusieurs étages divisés en nombreux appartements composés de pièces judicieusement distribuées, ventilées, éo airées et assainiee par l'adoption de tone les principes de l'bygiène la mieux comprise. Ces appartements pouront être cédés en location a des prix modostes, a partir de 3 L.E. par mois suivant les etages et le nombre de pièces dont ils se composeront.

Mr. Margtasoff Bey, Ingénieur an Caire, expert près les Tribunaux Mixtes, chargé par la Société de visiter le terrain, et d'en appréoier la valeur, a déclaré dans son rapport d'expertise qae la vente par lota pent rapporter on minimum de 75% de bénéfice. Nona avons lieu de croire que oette prévision sera dépassés de beauoonp.

Mr. Marichal, Ingénieur, expert piès les Tribunaux Mixtes d'Alexandrie, également consulté, a conclu après étude sur les lieux, que les oapitanx empli yés en constructions économiques élevées sur ce terrain pourraient obtenir un inté êt de 15% i'an net.

Toute somme dont le paiement est retardé porte de plein droit en favenr de la Sociéié, intérêt a 9% l'an a partir du jour de l'exigibilié sans demande eu justice.

A défant de versement a l'échéance, la Société a droit, un mois après publication des numéros des threaten retard dans an journal désigné ponr les annonces judiciaires an Caire, de faire procéder a la vente, en bloc on en déta 1, même a des époques sucoessives, des actions a la Bourse d'Alexandrie ou du Caire, par courtiers ou agents de charge, ponr le compte et anx risques et périls des retardataires sans mise en demeure ni formalités judiciaires.
Les titres ainsi vendus deviennent nais de plein droit et il en est délivré anx acquéreurs de nouveaux sous les mêmes naméros.
Tout titre qai ne porte pas mention régulière dn versement des sommes exigibles cesse d'être négociable.
Les mesures autorisées par le présent article ne font pas obstacle & l'exercice simultané par la Société des moyens ordinaires de droit.

Les prix provenant de la vente, déduction faite des frais, appartiennent a la Société et s'imputent, dans les termes de droit, sur ce qui est dû par l'actionnaire exproprié qui reste passible de la différence s'il y a.défiait, mais qui profite de l'excédent s'il eu existe.

PROSPECTUS
FONDATION DE LA SOCIÉTÉ —La Société Anonyme Tub Artbsian Boring & Prospecting Co. a été autorisée par Décret Khédivial do 15 Mai 1904.

OBJET —Elle a pour but : le forage et l'installation de pnits dits artésiens, soit ponr l'alimentation en ean potable des villes' et des particuliers, soit pour l'irrigation des terres; l'acquisition de terrains susceptibles d'ê re cultivés gifne a l'irrigation attésieune et antres ; l'exéoutinn de tontes sortes de sondages et forages profonds ponr recherches minières ; l'obtention et l'exploitation de toutes concessions de recherhes.
TRAVAUX EXE UTÉS :

a)IRRIGATIONS.—L-t Sooié'é a exécu'é depuis sa fondation nn grand nombre d'installations d'irrigation artériinne, et elle a en mainB ponr pins de L E 20 0l 0 de nouveaux contrats, dont plusieurs concernent des installations devant fournir chscnne environ 30.0(Ni m3 HVan par jour. Le nombre toojonrs croissant de corn mandes de pnits artésiens provient:
1* de oe que l'irrigation artésienne permet d'éviter les inconvénients du système des rotations ;
2* de la mise en onltnre de nombreux terrains auxquels fait défaut tonte irrigation par l'eao dn Nil.

b) ALIMENTATIONS EN EAU POTABLE —La Société a achevé plusieurs installations en ean potable pour le compte d'Administratious Gouvernementales et de particuliers, entre antres celle de la ville de Khartonm. Elle vient d'être chargés de l'exé cation de la partie bydranliqne pour les fournitures en ean potable de villes de Menonf et Zagzig.

c) FORAGES PROFONDS.—La Société nos ède des outillages à vapeor pour sondages et forages a grande profondeur. Un forage a 800 pieds a été fait a Port 8adan et un antre de 500 a 1,000 pieds de profondeur est en oonrs d'exéontion dans la même localité. Le Gouvernement a également chargé la 8ooiété de faire à Mersn Matrooh un toudage de 700 pieds ponr rechetohe d'ean douce. Un sondage de reoberche a été exécuté a 400 pieds de profondenr pour le oompte de l'Egyptiau Coal Syndicate.

CONCESSIONS.—La Soc'été a obtenu du Gouvernement ane concession de 5 100 teddaDs de terrsi-.s cultivables dans le district de Mersa Matrooh et de 12,000 m2 de terrain a bâtir le long du port de cette même localité.
Cette concession est appe'ée an pins grand avenir par snite de l'achèvement prochain dn chemin de fer oonstrnit par Son Altesse le Khédive sur la côte Ouest d'Alexandrie.

RESULTATS OBTENUS.—Il a été distribué 6% ponr le 1er exeroice; 9% ponr le 2me après amortfsseroent détona fiais de premier établissement et de 20 % sur la valeur du matériel. Les comptes arrô'éi provisoirement au 3 Novembre 1906 accusent déjà pour les 8 premiers mois du 3me exercises, actuellement en cours et se terminant le 31 Mars 1907, nn bénéfice de' pins de 20 % du capita', déduction faite de tous frais d'exploitation et d'administration. Les affaires actuellement conclues, dont la plus grande partie ne s'acheveront qu'au coars de l'exercice pro chain, assurent d'ores et déjà a elles sentes an bénéfice suffisant pour rémunéréa le nouveau capital émis.
AUGMENTATION DU CAPITAL.—Les fonds provenant de la nouvelle émissioi seront affecés princalement à :
1—La mise eu valeur de la concession de Mersa Matrooh.
2.—L'acquisition et la mise en valeur de terrains susceptibles d'être exploi é an moyen d'irrigation artésienne.
8. - L'extension des entreprises de forages profonds pour reoherohes minières.

La Société a déjà fait ses preuves. Les résultats qu'elle a pu obtenir ave nn capital aussi minime qae oelai dont elle e disposé jusqu'à présent, moutrent ce quelle pourra réaliser lorsque ses ressources lui permettront de porter son activité dans les diverses branohes que ses Statuts l'autorisent a exploiter.

div.head: Health and Comfort for All.
div.p: It is with pleasure that we inform our readers that a long felt want for rapidly heating a bath without troublt and expense has finally been solved by a newly invented rapid water heater specially made for use where gas does not exist. It can be heated with wood, charcol, coke, haddan, or any kind of fuel, and produces a hot bath (5ft. 6in.) in eight minutes. It is small in size, easily installed, and specially recommended for rented houses. the price is only P.T. 800, including installation expenses in Alexandria and suburbs, or packing and delivery free for any part of Egypt. If desired the amount may be payable in instalments of 100 P.T. per month. Further particulars of 100 P.T. per month. Further particulars may be obtained from Messr. Moros & Cotsos, Boulevard Ramleh No. 15, Alexandria, the sole agents for Egypt and the Sudan

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should foward all t estimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagments since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 er mensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted inot the Government service.
Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo.
ALexandria, January 17,1907.

div.head: PE-RU-NA DR. HARTMAN'S FAMOUS PRESCRIPTION THE TALK OF THE CONTINENT.
div.p: READ AND BE CONVICNED
Just A Few Of the Sincere Letter Written To Dr. Hartman By Honest People.
Owes Good Health to Pe-run-na.
Miss L.Wall, 350 N. Dale street, St. Paul Minn., writes: "Last Spring I had a very severe case of catarrh of the stomach and bowels. I was very much run down in strength and lost my appetite.
"I took three bottles of Peruna and found myself gaining very quickly in every way.
"I also had catarrh in my head, which has been entirely cured.
"I thank peruna for the health I am enjoying."
The World's Greatest Medicine Factory.
The rapid growth of the Peruna Medicine Company is as phenomenal in the business wordl as the universal populartiy of their most famous remedy, Peruna.
The plany covers a number of acres, and emplys several hundred people. No other medicine firm in the world reaches anything like the volume of business done by Dr. Hartman's firm.

Although Peruna is a proprietary medicine, the details of its compounding are in strict accordance with pharmaceutical discoveries and nothing give Dr. Hartman greater pleasure that to show his initimate professional friends through the laboratory where Peruna is made.
A Doctor's Prescription

For years Dr. Hartman used Peruna in his private practice as a regular prescription. He had no though of manufacturing it or advertising it as a propritary medicine until there was a demand made upon him by his many (illegible) who clamored for the original prescription.
Forty Thousand Patients.
Dr. Hartman estimates that he must have prescribed Peruna for over forty thusand patients before it was advertised as a proprietary medicine.
Relieved In Four Weeks of Sever Cold on Lungs,
Miss Josie Schaetzel, gen. Del., Appleton, Wis., writes:

"I contracted a severe cold which settled on my lungs in very short order and it was not long until it developed into a serious case of catarrh. Every morning I would raise a lot or phlegm, which was very disagreeable. My digestion was poor and my lungs sore.
"After a few doeses of peruna I began to mend, and felt that if I kept on taking it, it would not be long until I would be well. I was right, for in four weeks I was well again.
"I think Peruna is a grand medicine, and wish to add my testimony to many others you have."
Catarrh is almost universal. Catarrh is difficult to cure. Many doctors do not care to treat catarrh at all.
Followed Doctor Hartman's Advice -- A Grateful Letter.
Mrs. Anthony Rauch, 439 Johnston street, Bucyrus, Ohio, writes:
"I was suffering from obstinate constipation and torpid liver when I took your advice and purchased six bottles of Peruna and Manalin.
"When I had taken only one bottle I felt much better and since I have taken two more bottles I feel entirely well, but I will continue taking the mdicine for a short time to make sure of my cure.
"I think Manalin is one of the finest remedies for constipation that I ever tried. I will never be without it. It has made me so strong. I can do a day's work and never tire.
"I am so glad I do not get those dizzy spells any more. I havn't had one since I took your medicine.
"I cannot thank you enough for what your medicine has done for me. All sick people should give it a fair trial."
Pe-ru-na's Popularity.
Peruna is not like so many other remedies that pass away as soon as the first few bottles are used. The longer Peruna is used in any community, the more popular it becomes.
Finds Relief in Pe-ru-na After Suffering Twenty Years.
Mrs.M.S. Davis, 1505 Buena Vista street, Nashville, Tenn., writes:

"After having been a constant sufferer from catarrh for more than twenty years and after trying almost every remedy advertsed, and having lost all hope, I very reluctantly began the use of Peruna about two years ago.
"Everyone says I look younger now thatn I did twenty years ao, and I actualy feel younger and better, and weight more.
"I am recommending it to my neightbors and all with whom I come in contact."
Pe-ru-na removes the Cause of Catarrh.
Peruna has no bad effects upon the system and gradually eliminates catarrh by removing the cause of catarrh. There are a multitude of homes where Peruna has been used off and on for twenty years.
Pe-ru-na Actually Relieves.
The reason why Peruna has become a standard catarrh remedy the world over is simply because it eliminates catarrh.
This explains why Peruna has become so popular. It relives catarrh. This is an amply sufficient reason why it should become popular.
It therefore follows that when a remedy is devised that can be used in the home at a moderate cost, such a remedy should inevitably becomes popular.
Keeps Pe-ru-na in the House.
Mrs. Jessie Smith, 408 Buttles Ave., Columbus, Ohio, writes:
"I have used your Peruna for catarrh of the head and stomach, and have been greatly relived from it.
"Therefore I cannot praise Peruna too much and can recommend it to any one having the above disease, as there is nothing better.
"I always keep it in the house."
There are a great many catarh cures in the world. The most of them are local applications. Few of them are to be used internally.
Unfortunately, a large number of these cararrh remedies, espeically the ones prescribed by the doctors, contain narcotics of some sort. Cocaine, opium and other narcoties are used.
These remedies give temporary relief. The patient thinks he is better right away.
In a few weeks, however, he discovers his mistake. Not only is his catarrh no better, but he has aquired the habit of using some narcotic.

One reason why Peruna has found permanent use in so many homes is that it contains no narcotic of any kind. Peruna is perfeclty harmless, if taken according to directions on the bottle. So used, it can be taken any length of time without acquiring a drug habit.

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Pe-ru-na is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle of six bottles for twenty-five shillings. Those wishing direct correspondence with Dr. Hartman and can wait the necessary delay in reciveing a reply should address Dr. S. B. hartman, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A. The following wholesale druggist will supply the retail drug trade in Alexandria, Egypt.
Max Fischer, Cairo and Alexandria, Egypt.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

Que'ques personnes, bien mal inspirees, ne cessent de nous poursuivre de leurs tracasseries, croyany peut-etre faire de l'esprit, mais ne reussissany qu'a se rendre ridicules. Libre a elles de s'afficher, si cela est un genre de reclame qui leur convient, et de finir par devenir la risee du public; nous ne les suivrons pas sur ce terrain la; toutefois, ce que nous ponvons leur conseiller et ce que nous nous permettons de faire, c'est de cessar ces enfantillages qui ne sauraient leur etre d'auncune utilite.

Si nos idees ne cadrent pas avec les leurs, elles n'ont qu'a nous repondre par ecrit et elles peuvent compter que nous accorderons l'hospitalite a leur prose, pourvu que l'exposition de leurs argumentts soit faite sous une forme succinte.

En agissant de la sorte, d'avilleurs, elles feraient meilleure besogne et serviraient mieux leurs interests et ceux de leur parti qu'en continuant un jen qui, a force d'etre repere, finirait par devenir aussi monotone et aussi fatigant que le spectacle d'un moulin a farine qui ne fait que tourner du matin au soir! Elles dovient bein en savior queleuq chose!!
Ceci dit a l'adresses de qui de droit, venons a notre revue de marche.

La semina qui vient de finir a eu beaucoup de ressemblance avec celle qui l'a precedee, sinon dans le resultat definitivement obtenu, du moins dans son allure jusqu'aux derniers jours pres. En effet, de samedi a mercredi, la serie a la baisse a ete continue, a la plus grande joie des vendeurs et quoique, apres tout, le recul n'ait, ete que granduel et par petites e'tapes, il n'en est pas moins vrai que le mars avair fini par tomber a 20 29/32. A ce point, tout semblait perdu et les acheteurs avaient commence a disparaitre devant l'avslanche des vendeurs quand tout a coup le bruit a courn que de grosses affaires venaient d'etre faites avec la filature. Au fond, il n'y avaoit pas un mot de vrai dans la nouvelle qu'on venait de preandre, maiss ce qui est un fait, c'est qu'el'e n'a pas tarder a produire un revirement complet dan la tenue du marche en nous faisant remonter, en pen d'instants, a 21 3/32 pour finir en cloture a 21 1/16.

Ce peit jen qui constitue, dit-on un des truces souvent usites avec succres pour influencer la speculation, ne pouvant continuer longtemps, l'ouverture de ce matin eut lien em mauvaise tendance, mai sur l'annonce faite presque immediatement que les exportations de la huitaine depassaient de beaucoup les previsions, une reprise de 1/8 s'est dessinee et s'est maintenue en depit des effors de baissiers, avec des fluctuations de 1/32 dans les daux sens, pours nous faire terminer la jounes sur lacote de 2 13/16, soit au meme niveau qu Vendredi dernier; seul pont du reste sur lequel la semanie a differe de sa devanciere.

Comme on le voit le seul point d'appui derieux de la speculation a ete la question de l'exportation, mias comme la chose est importante, on ne sauair blamer ceuz aui s'y sont bases. Certes, une diminution et meme tres sensible se produria sous peu dans nos embarquements de Fevier, mais aucune assertion a ce sujet ne saurair avoir de 'effet sur la speculation, devenue sceptique, et qui coudra attendre le fait accompli pour y croire. Les baissiers n'ont donc qu'a patiner, d'autant plus que malgre les nouelles d'Amerique et malgre l'hesitation qui regne, les haussiers feront tout pour maintenir les cours, dans le secret espoir peutetre que dans l'entre-temps la demande pourrait venir a leur secours de la part de la consom mation.

A ce propos, nous devons mentionner ce qui se dit parmi les exportateirs : tont le monde est d'accord sur le point que les affaires qui se font actuellement n'out aucune importance, quoiqu'il s'en tasse tous les jours; mais c'est sur ce qui conernce la suite qu les ides on les appreciations sont tout-a-fair en contradiciton. Le fait est que les uns se disent fondres a prevoir une continuation de l'abstention de la filature et pour longtemps meme, tandies que les autres se croient justifies on affirmean que le reviel de la demande est a la veillle de se fair remarquer, que les offres fermes sont constamment sollicitees de la part de la consommation et non pourquanitites insignifiantes.

Nous admettons d'une facon absolue que des deux cotes les renseignements sont donnes avec une entiere bonne foi; mais comment peut on en arrivier entre deux courants d'opinion si differents, a connature la verite exacte sur les dispositions on les besoins de la filature? Nul doute que notre recolte n'est pas toute vendue et qu'il y aura de la demande pour le restant de notre recolte, tout au moins pour une partie, mais y a-til deja urgence on la filature continuera-t elle a lutter pour que que temps encore? Dans le prier cas, la speculation serait sauvee a bref delai, mais dans le second c'est la fatigue qui finirait par douver le coup de grace et que que pour notre part, nous penchions pour lad basi se, tant a cause de l'inaction actuelle pour le dohors, qu par suite de la perspective d'une gorsse filiere pour Mars, ne fut-ce qu'en vue des repors evec la position si surchargee de la petite speculation, nous n'en demeurona pas moins perplexe sur l'importance de cette baisse. Sans tous les cas, neus ne partageons pas l'avis de ceux qui pensent teujours que les cours de 19 tallaris
et au-dessous sont certains un peu plus tard. Tout est possible a la bourse, mail il faudrait d'autres circonstances pour en arriver a ce point.

La meme divergence d'opinions existe aussi sur la question des probabilites des embarquemenets en Fevrier et les appreciations que nous avons entendues sont de 25 a 50% de reduction. Naurellement chacun juge d'apres sa position et d'apres ses engagements, mais la generalite semble pencher pour le 30% sauf le cas de nouvelles affaires qu'uue baisse eventuelle pourrait amener ou faciliter.

La vielle recolte a ete suffisamment active, quoique pas d'une maniere suivie; mais ce qu'il y a de plus saillant c'est la tenue dautant plus suprenante qu l'activite ay fond y a fait peut-etre defaut. Le fait est que la Novembre gagne 3/16 pour la semaine, le cours de cloture ce soir etnat de 18 5/8; toutefois ce resultat n'a rien de bien extraordinaire, etnat donne l'importance du de'couvert qui aidera toujours les haussiers dans leur ache a laquelle viennent se greffer les affaires avec la filature sur la campagne prochaine. Il n'y a pas de gros chifres a mentinner, mais ce qui s'y passe suffir pour valoir aux acheteurs l'aide de l'exportation qui doit bein covier ses ventes a la consommation, qu'eles soient grandes on petites. N'oublions cependant pas qu'une poussee exageree des cours pourrait tout modifier peut-etre.

En Amerique, c'est la baisse qui continue a faire des progress et, franchement, il faur bien croire q'il doit y avoir plus de coton qu'on ne les disait on qu'on ne le pensait. Et poutant le cours de 5 ½, a que'ques rare exceptions pres, est considere par le monde contonnier comme etant modere pour la consommation existante. Il est vrai que d'anucuns parlent de surproduction et de revirement dans la situation prospere de l'industrie, mais ces propheties semblent viser une echeance eloignee pour l'annee prochaine car avec ce que l'on sait sur les engagments deja pris par la filature, aucune apprehension n'eiste et ne peut exister pour une periodes de dix a douze mois.

Notre marche du disponsible a manque d'entrain, mais malfre tout c'est la fermete qui a predomine. Le point incontestable est que les classements liverables contrats one tete notes avec ¼ de tallari de hausse, tandis qu'an moment de l'establissment de la cote, les course de contrats etaient identiques a ceuz de la semaine passee au neme moment. Cela diminue la marge de arbitragistes, mais dela n'arretera par leus operations, la difference entre le spot et le mars etant toujours de nature a rassasier tous les appetuts, quelques voraces qu'ils pussent etre.
Ave leur total de 32,000 balles, contre quantite egale en 1906, les exportations on depasse de 6,000 balles les previsions du commencement de la semaine. Nouce avouons que

nous ne nous attendions pas a celle-la, cardans ces conditions la reduction pour la quinzaine n'est que de 4,000 balles en tout an lieu de 10,000 balles a ce que nous pensions. Inutile de chercher une justification quelconque, les chiffres etant indiscutables.

Les recettes continuent a etre sure une base plus reduites qu'auparavant, ce qui n'exclut pas que les idees de 6 ¾ et meme de 7 millions de cantars sont quand meme a l'orde du jour. Les 6 ½ ne sont preconises que par la minorite qui a peut etre ses raisons.

Liverpool a ete relativement favorable aux egyptiens disponibles, tant comme ventes que sous le rapport des prix, le tout cependant das une mesure moderee. Le cote de ce jout nous montre une hausse de 1/16 pour le spot qui vaut 10 7/16 et 10/64 pour les futures qui on fini a 10 15/64 pour le mars.

Les Americains aussi ont ete d'une activite limitee, mais pour ce qui est des prix, il y a de 2 a 3 points de baisse a signaler sur toute la ligne, les cours de ce jour ayant fini a 5.87 pour le spot a 5.49 pour le mars-avril et 5.43 pour le julliet-aout.
Graines de Coton.

Les reettes qui n'onte ete que d'Ard. 124000 asont restees de 50000 balles au-dessous des besions de l'exportation qui se sont chiffres pour la semaine par Ard. 174.000; aussi, la consequence a-telle ete la fermete et la hausse dans le prix du spot qui a fini a P.R. 73 ½.
La tendance aussi est donne, car les embar quements de la semaine prochaine promettent d'etre importants.

En contrats, il n'y a eu que des affaires limitees, mais la lus grande fermete n'a cesse de prevaloir. La deniere cloture nous montre le fevrier-Mars a P.T. 75,10, soit a peine de 10 40 en reaction sur le maximum pratique. Hull avait flechi a 6.18/9.1 pour le Janvier, mas par suite de la situation des huiles et du mauvais temps qui regne de non veau et qui attire la demande pour les tour teaux, le Fevrier nous vient aujourd'hui a 7 3/9. On dit pourtant que les achats sont purement apeculatifs pour compte des fabricatns de savon.
les premiers gros arrivages en graines de coton de bombay sont attendus en Anglterre vers le 15 coyrant.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: L'amerlioration de marche monetair modial suit une progression lente, mais ininterompue. De 4 7.8% le taux prive d'escompte a ete encore eduit cette semaine a 4 5/8 %. La reserce de la Banque d'Angleterre ne s'est pas sensiblement modifiee; elle est de 48 3/8%. Quant aux valeurs egyptiennes, elles font preuve a Londres d'une fermete de bon augure: la Daria etl'Agricole gagnent 1/8 aux cours respectifs de 17 7/8 et 9 7/8 et la National Bank ¼ a 28 5/8; la Delta Light se maintient a 11 ½. La rente francaise 3% beneficie d'une reprise de 37 centrimes a a 95.12. En revanche, la Consolide anglais perd 1/8 a 87.

Sur notre place, les nouvelles emissions, si nombreuses, on ie produit un drainage momentane de numeraire, drainage qui a occasionne un recul sure quelques-uns de nos meilleurs titres; mais, en depit de cette circonstance defavorable, l'ensemble de notre marche a ete cette semaine, remarquablement actif et haussier. le fair est que sur une soizantaine de valeirs, niscites a la cote officielle de notre bourse, 20 sont en reprise, 15 seulement en baisse et les autres demeurent soutenues aux cours anterieurs.

Les fluctuations les plus sensibles sont: a la la hausse, l'Agrucole qui gagne 1.4 a 9 7/8, la Dividende Tramways 5 fr. a 365, les Jouissances Eaux de Caire 6 fr. a 298 la Daria 3/8 a 17 ¾, la Cassa Sconto 7 et 6 fr. a 284 l'ancienne et 278 la nouvelle, la Line Land 1 livre 1.4 a 19 1/4, l'Urbaine 7/16 a 7 7/8, l'Allotment 3/6 a 3 11/16 et la Port Said Salt 2 shellings 6 pence a 15/9; a la baisse, la Biere du Caire qui perd 4 fr. a 128 la Privilegiee et 64 la Dividende, et la part de fondateur Comptoir 6 livres a 94.
Plusieurs evenements financiers importants se sont deroules au cours de cette semaine. Nous allons ;acher de resumer les principaus d'entre eux.

Le Societe d'Enterprises Urbaines et Rurales a vendu a M. Ch. Bacos son terrain de la Rue Rosette comprenant le theatre Zinzina, le consualt d'Autriche-Hongrie et les Galeries Lafayette pour la somme de 150,000 livres. L'etendue totale du terrain etant de 13730 pic, le prix de vente est ainsi de p e de 11 livres le poc. Si l'on considere qu l'Urbaine avait achete le pic a raison de 5 livres, on voit que cette societe a realise dans cette seule affairs un benefices de plus de cent. La valeur des terrains a augmente dans de telles proportions au cours de ces deux dernieres annees qu'on en estime pas moins que le Nile Land and Agricultural a fair la un marche tres avantageux.
Nous apprenons de bonne source que l'Union Fonciere vient de recvoir une offre d'achat

pour mille feddans de sa propriete de Ghabieh a raison de 100 livres le feddan. Le terrain en question ne lui a coute que 55 livres le feddan, mais comme la plus-value de terrains lui assure des pix encore plus avantageux, la societe a refuse cette offre. C'est a cette nouvelle qu'il faut attribeur la reprise de ce matin, sans compter qu de gros portefeuilles ramassent discretement le titre depuis que'que temps deja.

Il a couru dernierement le bruit que les pouparlers de fusion entre la Salt & Soda et la Port Said Salt avainet ete repris. la verite est que ces deux societes sont arrivees enfin a une ente le pour mettre fin a une concurrence ruineise pour toutes deux. De la provient la hausse de 1 shelling 3 pence sur la Salt & Soda et de 2 shellings 6 pence sur la Port Said Salt.

Parmi les nouvelles emissions on nous annonce pour les 7 et 8 fevrier celle de l'Anglo Egyptian Finance and Exchange Compant Limited (Lunghis), scoiete constituee sans actions de jouissance ni parts de fondateur. Le captial est de 200,000 en actions de 1. 67,000 de ces actions seulement sont offertes a la souscription publique, solde ayant ete souscrit ferme par le syndicat de formation. La societe a pour but les operations de banque, de courtage, etc.

MM. Arditi and Co., agents de cahnge des plus ancienne ment et avantageusement conuus d'Akexandrie et du Caire, transforment aussi leur etablissement en Societe anonyme, sous le nom de Bourse and Banking Company of Egpyt, Limite. La nouvelle societe prendra la suite des affaires de la maison Arditi and Co. et aura pour objet principal les operations de courtage en fonds publics et marchandises aux Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, ainsi que les arbitrages entre ces deux places et les Bourse etrangeres. Le captial intital est de 125,000 dont 120,000 en actions ordinaires de 1 et 5,000 en deferred de 1 egalement; ce capital pourra dans la shuite etre porte a 500,000 sur simple decision du Conseil d'Administration.

Les Egyptian Markets ayant resolu de se liver a l'importation des engrais de nitrate vont proceder a l'emission restante de 50,000, necessaire pour cet objet/ Le prix d'emission est fixe a 27 sh. 6 pence, la prime de 7 sh. 6d. devant etre portes a la reserve. Le titre en bourse beneficie de 6 pence a 31 shellings.

Dans la deuxieme quonzaine de fevrier aura lien l'emission de 100.000 actions/ordinaries Khedivial Mail de 1 a 1.7.6. La prime sera portee a la reserce. les porteirs actuels auront a la souscription un droit de preference dans la proportion de 71 actions nouvelles pour 100 anciennes. 7 sh. 6 sont payables a la souscription et le solde a la reparition. Les nouveaux titres participerout auc benefices a partir de la repartition. L'Ordinary cote en bourse 34/6, soit une perle de 9 pence la semaine.

P us proche de nous, c'est a dire lundi prochain a lien l'emission de l'Upper Egypt Hotels a raison de L.E. 4 ½ l'action de L.E. 4. Le nombre a emettre e ant de 22,000 actions, les poreurs actuels ont un droit de preference a la sonscription de 2 actions nouvelles pour 5 anciennes. Il doit etre paye 1 L.E. a la souscription, 1 ½ L.E. a la repartition et le solde sur appels ulterieurs du conseil d'administration. Le cours en bourse est de 4 11/16, ce qui n'a rien d'exagere pour une valeur dont on estime le prochain coupon a un taux remunerateur.

La reprise de 5/32 sur la Delta Land a 4 9/16 est due a la decision prise ces jours ci par l'assemblee du consil de reduire le nombre des administrateurs anglais a 3 et de porter celui des administrateurs locaux a 4, donnant ainsi la majorite aux membres egyptiens. Le Gouvernements a de plus renconce ay projet de fixer le champ d'epandage a proximite de la proptiete de la Delta Land entre Meadi et Tourah. Ce sont deux bonnes nouvelles pour la societe.

emission le 4 coutant de la Ghezireh Mansions Ltd. au captial de 200,000. Cette societe vient d'acheter 10000 metres de la Ghezireh Palace (Baehler) qu'elle compte exploiter. 40,000 actions de 1 seront offertes a la souscription publique.

div.p: This Prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies.
THE SUBSCRIPTION LIST will be opened at the Anglo Egpytian Bank Limited at Cairo, Alexnadria on THURSDAY the 7TH day of February, 1907, and closed on or before FRIDAY, the 8th day of February 1907.
(Incorporated under the Companies Acts, 1862 to 1900.)
Capital ... 200,000
Divided into 200,000 shares of 1 each.
There are no Preference, Deferred, or Founders Shares.
No underwriting commission has been or will be paid.
The Directors now offer 67,000 shares to the Public, payable as follows: --
5/- per share on application.
5/- per share on allotment.
The balance as may be called by the Directors, at intervals of not less than three calendar months:
97,000 shares have been subscribed for by the Memorandum of Association.
Directors.
AMBROISE RALLI, Alexandria, Direcor of the National Bank of Egypt, Chairman.
HECTOR VON PITNER, Alexandrie, General Agent of the Austrian Llyod S.S. Company.
T. COZZIKAS, Alexandria, Manufacturer.
CONSTANTIN PILAVACHI, Alexandira, Director of the Building Lands of Egpyt.
G. MINIAKIS, Cairo, Mercahnt.
ACHILLE LUNGHIS, Cairo, Stock Broker.
Managing Director.
ACHILLE LUNGHIS.
Assistant Manger in Alexandira.
ARTHUR SPAGNOLO.
Bankers.
THE ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK LIMITED, Cairo, Alexandria and Branches.
Legal Adviser.
DR. D. DEMETRIADES, 9 rue Debbane, Alexandira.
Auditors.
Messrs. RUSSELL, KERR, and WYATT, Cario, Alexandria and London.
Secretary and Registered Office.
REGINALD C. WATSON, 30 Bedford Row, London.
Local Secretary and Offices.
JOHN SCHILIZZI, Alexandira.
PROSPECTUS.

This Company haa been formed for the objects set out in the Company's Memoran dum of Association, including the acquisition of the clientele and business of the partnership "eh commandite" carried on at Cairo and Alexandria under the style of A. LUNGHIS & Co. as from ths 1st January 1907, the carrying on of the business of stock, share and produce brokers, and the undertaking of Exchange, Bourse, Financial and Commercial operations and transactions of all kinds.

The Company intends forthwith to commence business at Cairo and Alexandria and for that purpose has entered into arrangements for the conduct of its affairs on the Bourses at, Cairo and Alexandria and will enter into such other arrangements as may be neoessary.
The Directors and friends have subscribed the Company's Memorandum cf Association for 97,000 shares.

The Vendors, Messrs. Achille Lunghis & Co, Bhow their confidence in the Company's future by not only accepting the whole of the purchase consideration payable to them entirely in fully paid shares and subscribing for 90,000 shares by the Company's Memoran dum of Association, but they have also agreed to deposit with the Company 50,000 fully paid shares to the intent that the said 50,000 shares shall not be sold or dealt with by them as to 30,000 during the period of three years from the date of the Company incorporation, and as to 20,000 during the period of one year from the same date.
The whole of the purchase consideration, namely £36,000, to be paid in fully paid share- represents the agreed value of the goodwill.
The Company has secured the sevices of Mr. Achille Lunqius as its Managing Director for a period of five years from the date of the incoporation of the Company.
The services of Mr. Arthur Spagnolo, until recently "fonde de pouvoirs" of the Credit Lyonnais at Alexandria, bave also been retained for a like period, as Assistant Manager.
The Articles of Association contain the following provisions:

94 Ae remuneration for their services the Directors (other than the Managing Direotor) shall be paid at the rate of £100 per annum for each ordinary Director and at the rate of £260 per annum for the Chairman.
Provided, nevertheless, that if in any year a dividend at the rate of at least £6 per annum is not paid, the remuneration of the Directors shall be at one half of the before mentioned rate.

In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company in general meeting may from time to time determine. An alternate Director appointed under Article 90 hereof shall not as such be entitled to any remuneration.

95. Any Direotor may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the Company, except that of Auditer of the Company, and may aot either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional services to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be oalled upon to perform extra service or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or in negotiating or qarrying into effect any ooutraot or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or aot as Trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum or a percentage of profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for his remuneration above provided, If any Direotor shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Direotor of any subsidiary or other Company in which the Company shall be interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own use.
CONTRACTS.
The following contracts have been entered into:—

An agreement dated the 20th day of November 1906 between the members of the partnership firm "eu commandite" A. Lunghis & Co. namely, Achille Lunghis, Gèo Miniakis, Constantin Rezzos, Maria Kavnffi, Michel Sa'vago, of ths first part, Cleon Lunghis of the second part and Charles H. Lloyd of the 3rd part whereby the said firm A Lunghis & Co agreed to sell to the Company its busiuss as a going concern including the goodwil1, pending contracts, and agreements for tenancy, as at the 1st January 1907.

An agreement dated the 27th December 1906 between the Company and Mr. Achille Lunghis providing for the appointment of the latter as Managing Director of the Company for a period of five years at a salary of 1,000 pounds per annum and a percentage of 3% of the gross profits of the Company remainin in each year after deductions of general expenses
An Agréemént dated the 27th day of December 1906 between the Company and Arthur apagnolo providing for the appointment of the latter as Assistant Manager and for his remuneration as such.
GENERAL.
The amount fixed by the Articles as to minimum subscription upon which the Directors may prooeed to allotment is £l0 000.
The preliminary expenses payable by the Company are estimated at £3,000.

By the Articles the Directors have power to increase the capital of the Company by the creation of new shares of each an amouut as they may deem expedient not exceeding with the original capital, £1,000,000/
A copy of the Memorandum of Association which forms part of this prospectus is endorsed hereon.
Applocations for shares should be made on the accompanying form, and fowarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers.

If no allotment is made the application money wil be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less that that applied for, the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment whem due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The above mentioned contracts or copies of thereof, together wth a print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the offices of the Company in Cairo and Alexandira.
opies of the Prospecuts and application forms can be obtained at the said offices of the Company or from the Bankers.
Dated this 22nd day of January 1907.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Vendredi 1er Fevrier 1907.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient d'être encore réduit de 1/8 à 4 5/8 pour cent, signe qne la situation monétaire tend décidément à s'améliorer. An Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé hier de 1/8 à 87, et l'Unifiée de 1/4 a 102 1/2. La National Bank a, par contre, haussé de 3/3 à 28 5/8. La Daïra a également gagné 8/3 à 17 7/8. L'Agricole est restée iovariée à 9 7/8, de môme que la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a progressé de 1 frano à 778. La Banqoe d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 137.

Ici, la tenne d'ensemble dn marché a été encore meilleure qu'hier grâie, d'une part, à la détente dn resserrement monétaire, à l'attitnde favorable des places dirigeantes, et, d'antre part, au fait qoe la liquidation à Alexandrie Bannonoe beaucoup moins laborieuse qu'on ne le prévoyait ; il paraîtrait qu'nne bonne partie des positions, déjà allégées dans le oonrant dn mois, a été reportée à fin février. Aussi bien, sauf oas imprévu, tout porte à oroire à nne aooentoation de la reprise qui s'est dessillée depuis denx jours.

Dans le compartiment dps Banques, la National s'est raffermie à 28 1/1. Eu fort bonnes dispositions, l'Agricole a haussé, sur de gros eohate, juqu'à 10 pour o'ôturer a 9 7/8-15/16 ; on confirme que le prochain dividende sera de 8 à 9 shellings. La Banque d'Abyssinie a fléchi a 5.

Le Crédit Foncier est resté a 778. La Daïre a avancé a 17 8/4 13/16. La Nile Land s'est tenne entre 19 et 19 1/4. L'Immobilière a gagné 7 francs a 388. Eu excellente teudame, 1'Enterprise and Development a avancé a 13 13/16 7/8 et sa part a 22 3/1.

Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été cotées L.E. 15 en clôture et leur part à P.E 303, ooars dérivant de la rareté dès tranractions. Ou s'attend généralement en Bourse à des prix plas élevés sur ces titres dès qne les affaires auront repris dans le ooura de la semaine prochaine.
L'Epargne Immobilière s'est traitée à 3 5/8 et sa pirt à 292. L'Express Nile est remontée à 5 5/8 et sa part à 315.
Les Jonissanoes Eaux dn Caire ont faibli à 294-295. Les Automobiles ont été mieux tonnes à 6 et leur part à 11.

Dans le gronpe des valeurs hôtelières, 1rs Nuegovioh ont, été négociés à 23 1/16-1/8. Les Egyptian se Bont raffermis a 12 13/16. Les Upper Egypt ont progressé à 4 8/4-13/16. Les Exoelsior se sont tassés à 4 3/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, il y a eu un très bon mouvement sur la Delta Land, qui a avancé à 4 5/8. Les Estâtes sont restés à 2 5/8 ; leur part a réaotionné a 22 5/8 8/4. Les Abdy ont progressé a 1 3/8 Les Sait and Soda se sont alourdis a 24 sh.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire do Crédit Foncier Egyptien a été tenue hier dans l'après- midi, an siège social an Caire, sons la présidence de M. Raphaël Suares.
Les comptes et bilan de l'exercice 1906 ort été approuvés. Le compte des profits et porter montre que les bénéfices acquis ont été d L.E. 331,368.
La dividende a été fixé a 17 franos pour les aotions de oapital et a 400 franos pour les pans de fondateur.
L'assemblée a désigné comme censeurs pour Texeroice 1907 MM. R Fieri et E. Bertby.

Nous tenons a la disposition de nos leoteuf- le plan de lotissement des terrains, sitïlés a Gherzireb, sur le bord du Nil, de la Société d'Entrepiises Immobilières et de Travaox. ainsi que les conditions de participation pour leur revente.
Désirant augmenter le nombre de nos lecteurs, nous prions nos amis de vonloir bien noos faire oonnaltre les noms des personnes qui voudraient recevoir notre Cironlaire.

div.head: STRICTURE AND KIDNEY DISEASE
div.p: 54, Brighton Place, Hampton Square,
Sheen Lane, Mortlake,
London, England

For nearly 19 years I suffered from stricture and kidney disease, and many a time have 1 laid on the bedroom floor writhing in agony. Twice I have been in hospital and undergone operations for the stricture. Never, as long I live, shall 1 forget what I went through then. The doctors said I could not live another three months, yet I can truly say that, although two years have passed since then, I was never better in my life than I am to-day.

My illness came on in this way: One day at my work I strained my back, and afterwards' I suffered from severe cutting pains, just over where the kidneys are, especially when I stooped. 1 could not sleep well, at nights, and there were distressing urinary disorders. I was miserable and out of sorts, and although the doctor did all he could for me, I got worse instead of better. If I had a glass of beer it irritated my kidneys so much that 1 had to keep to my bed for a week, but since using Doan's Backache Kidney Pills I can enjoy my glass without feeling a bit the worse for it.

It wasn't until I had finished the fourth box of Doan's Pills that they seemed to be doing me any good, but I persisted with the medicine, and with the fifth box there was a decidedly freer action of the bladder. No other medicine had ever helped me at all. and you can imagine how delighted 1 was at this relief. For six months I continued with Doan's Backache Kidney Bills, and then I was entirely on red of the stricture and kidney disease. From that day to this there hasn't been any sign of the old compaints returning.
(Signed) GEO, PRIEST
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box.

div.head: OUR SUDAN
div.p: ONLY WORK ON ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SUDAN.
REISSUE JUST OUT.
CONTAINING
AN Orographical Map of the while Nile Basin.
By JOHN WARD, F.S.A
AUTHOR OF "EGYPT ITS PYRAMIDS AND PROGRESS"
Dedicated by request to
Lord Kitchener or Khartoum.
Crown 4to. 400 pp. 720 Illustrations
PRICE 21s. net.
Letter from Sir Rudolph von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward,-- Your delightful and most interesting book on the Soudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illsutrated. All of us who have done out little best to regenerate the country, after its terrile misfourtunes, have recieved more that kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anoyone realises more that I do the change that has come over the SUdan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the "Peace an Progress" is in fact, a sequrl to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.'
With kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely,
RUDOLF V. SLATIN.
London, JOHN MURBAY. - Cairo F. DERMER.

div.p: W.B HOBBS, Secretary
R. BALFOUR, ARTHUR J. FRASER } Directors
In accordance with the provisions of the Companies Act, 1900, we certify that all our requirements as Auditors have been complied with.

We have examined the Securities representing Investments of the Company those held against Loans at call, short and fixed dates, and all Bills discounted in hand. We have also proved the Cash Balances, and, verified the Securities and Bills in the hands of Depositors. The foregoing Accounts agree with the Books, and we of opinion that the Balance Sheet is properly drawn up so as to exhibit a true and correct view of the state of the Company's affairs as shown by the Books of the Company, except that, whilst it shows the amount of the Bills discounted which have been re-discounted, it does not show the amount of the Bills and other Securities given out against Loans shown on the debit side of the Balance Sheet.
LONDON, E.C 7th January, 1907.
THOMAS A. WELTON} Auditors.
(Welton, Jones & Co.)
ADAM T. YOUNG,} Auditors.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic

THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
